abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Food
            Price Response Project for Nicaragua are to mitigate the
            negative nutritional impact of the food price increase on
            pre-primary and primary school children and to promote poor
            rural households' food security by increasing
            agricultural production. Nicaragua has been severely hit by
            the increase in food prices. Food inflation is amongst the
            highest in the region, reaching an annual inflation rate of
            28.8 percent in October 2008 after reaching a peak of 34.2
            percent in August 2008. The vast majority of households in
            Nicaragua are net food consumers, even in rural areas. This,
            combined with the large share of expenditures devoted to
            food in poor households' expenditures suggests that the
            impact of the crisis on poverty will be dire. Recent
            estimates place the decrease in real consumption for poor
            urban households at around 16 percent. In response to the
            food crisis, the Government of Nicaragua has adopted a
            two-pronged strategy that to a large extent is consistent
            with the recommendations issued by the Bank for countries
            facing a food prices crisis emergency. This strategy
            combines actions to support the most vulnerable groups of
            the population and actions aimed at expanding the supply of
            agricultural goods.
